* Sparse Mode = Uses a shared distribution tree & creates an optimal Shortest Path Tree (SPT) by using standby routers for switchover.

To ensure smooth video delivery in an HDMI over IP solution, the network administrator would most likely use Jumbo frames. Jumbo frames are Ethernet frames that are larger than the standard maximum transmission unit (MTU) size of 1500 bytes, allowing more data to be transmitted in a single frame. Link aggregation control, port tagging, and media access control (MAC) are not directly related to ensuring smooth video delivery in an HDMI over IP solution. Link aggregation control is the process of combining multiple physical ports into a logical port to increase bandwidth and provide redundancy. Port tagging is the process of marking network traffic with a specific VLAN ID to ensure that it is routed to the correct destination. MAC is a hardware address that uniquely identifies each device on a network. While these techniques may be useful for managing and optimizing network traffic, they are not specifically related to video delivery in an HDMI over IP solution.

Enabling jumbo frames can improve network performance by making data transmissions more efficient. The CPUs on switches and routers can only process one frame at a time. By putting a larger payload into each frame, the CPUs have fewer frames to process.
